long_description: Predict the category of the document in each text column

input_tables.name: input
input_tables.rDescription: The relation contains the text to be scanned
input_tables.description: The relation contains the text to be scanned

input_tables.name: dict
input_tables.rDescription: The relation that contains the dictionary for segementing words.
input_tables.description: The relation that contains the dictionary for segementing words.

argument_clauses.name: TextColumn
argument_clauses.rDescription: Specifies the name of the input table column that contains the text to tokenize
argument_clauses.description: Specifies the name of the input table column that contains the text to tokenize

argument_clauses.name: Accumulate
argument_clauses.rDescription: Specifies the names of the input table columns to copy to the output table.
argument_clauses.description: Specifies the names of the input table columns to copy to the output table.

argument_clauses.name: Language
argument_clauses.rDescription: Specifies the language of the text in text_column:  en (English, the default),  zh_CN (Simplified Chinese),  zh_TW (Traditional Chinese),  jp (Japanese)
argument_clauses.description: Specifies the language of the text in text_column:  en (English, the default),  zh_CN (Simplified Chinese),  zh_TW (Traditional Chinese),  jp (Japanese)

argument_clauses.name: OutputDelimiter
argument_clauses.rDescription: Specifies the delimiter for separating tokens in the output. The default value is slash (/).
argument_clauses.description: Specifies the delimiter for separating tokens in the output. The default value is slash (/).

argument_clauses.name: OutputByWord
argument_clauses.rDescription: Specifies whether to output one token in each row. The default value is 'false' (output one line of text in each row).
argument_clauses.description: Specifies whether to output one token in each row. The default value is 'false' (output one line of text in each row).

argument_clauses.name: userDictionaryFile
argument_clauses.rDescription: Specifies the name of the user dictionary to use to correct results specified by the model. If you specify both this argument and a dictionary table (dict), then the function uses the union of user_dictionary_file and dict as its dictionary. That describes the format of user_dictionary_file and dict. Note: If the function finds more than one matched term, it selects the longest term for the first match.
argument_clauses.description: Specifies the name of the user dictionary to use to correct results specified by the model. If you specify both this argument and a dictionary table (dict), then the function uses the union of user_dictionary_file and dict as its dictionary. That describes the format of user_dictionary_file and dict. Note: If the function finds more than one matched term, it selects the longest term for the first match.

argument_clauses.name: Model
argument_clauses.rDescription: Specifies the name of model file that the function uses for tokenizing. The model must be a conditional random-fields model and model_file must already be installed on the database. If you omit this argument, or if model_file is not installed on the database, then the function uses white spaces to separate English words and an embedded dictionary to tokenize Chinese text. Note: If you specify Language('jp'), the function ignores this argument.
argument_clauses.description: Specifies the name of model file that the function uses for tokenizing. The model must be a conditional random-fields model and model_file must already be installed on the database. If you omit this argument, or if model_file is not installed on the database, then the function uses white spaces to separate English words and an embedded dictionary to tokenize Chinese text. Note: If you specify Language('jp'), the function ignores this argument.
